Using fwapgr

Source: vignettes/fwapgr.Rmd
fwapgr.Rmd

Let’s make a map of the Yakoun River watershed

Check out the metadata

We’ll start by looking at the available layers

fwapgr::fwa_list_layers()
#> # A tibble: 28 x 7
#>    f_table_catalog f_table_schema f_table_name f_geometry_colu… coord_dimension
#>    <chr>           <chr>          <chr>        <chr>                      <int>
#>  1 postgis         whse_basemapp… fwa_manmade… geom                           2
#>  2 postgis         whse_basemapp… fwa_watersh… geom                           4
#>  3 postgis         whse_basemapp… fwa_linear_… geom                           2
#>  4 postgis         whse_basemapp… fwa_streams… geom                           4
#>  5 postgis         whse_basemapp… fwa_waterbo… geom                           4
#>  6 postgis         whse_basemapp… fwa_coastli… geom                           2
#>  7 postgis         whse_basemapp… fwa_lakes_p… geom                           2
#>  8 postgis         whse_basemapp… fwa_named_w… geom                           2
#>  9 postgis         whse_basemapp… fwa_approx_… geom                           2
#> 10 postgis         whse_basemapp… fwa_stream_… geom                           3
#> # … with 18 more rows, and 2 more variables: srid <int>, type <chr>

…and which columns are in the ‘fwa_stream_networks_sp’ layer

fwapgr::fwa_list_columns('fwa_stream_networks_sp')

#>    field_name               field_type

#> 10 length_metre             float8    
#> # … with 17 more rows

Get stream, watershed and lake data

Let’s get Yakoun river from the ‘fwa_stream_networks_sp’ layer. We will include the ‘blue_line_key’ column as it will come in handy later.

yakoun <- fwapgr::fwa_feature("fwa_stream_networks_sp",
                              filter = "gnis_name = 'Yakoun River'",
                              columns = c("blue_line_key"))

yakoun
#> Simple feature collection with 129 features and 1 field
#> geometry type:  MULTILINESTRING
#> dimension:      XYZ
#> bbox:           xmin: -132.2789 ymin: 53.34324 xmax: -132.1283 ymax: 53.65705
#> z_range:        zmin: 1 zmax: 99
#> CRS:            4326
#> First 10 features:
#>    blue_line_key                       geometry
#> 1      360881586 MULTILINESTRING Z ((-132.26...
#> 2      360881586 MULTILINESTRING Z ((-132.19...
#> 3      360881586 MULTILINESTRING Z ((-132.14...
#> 4      360881586 MULTILINESTRING Z ((-132.26...
#> 5      360881586 MULTILINESTRING Z ((-132.27...
#> 6      360881586 MULTILINESTRING Z ((-132.20...
#> 7      360881586 MULTILINESTRING Z ((-132.26...
#> 8      360881586 MULTILINESTRING Z ((-132.27...
#> 9      360881586 MULTILINESTRING Z ((-132.14...
#> 10     360881586 MULTILINESTRING Z ((-132.27...

Often we don’t know the valid gnis_name or column names to filter by. We could have used these convenience functions instead.

yakoun2 <- fwapgr::fwa_search_gnis_streams("yakoun") %>%
  fwapgr::fwa_gnis_streams()

Now let’s get the Yakoun River watershed. It requires a blue_line_key, which we will get from the ‘blue_line_key’ column of the stream layer.

blue_line_key <- unique(yakoun$blue_line_key)
wshed <- fwapgr::fwa_watershed(blue_line_key)

Let’s get all lakes within the bounds of the Yakoun River watershed. We will use sf package to get the bounding box.

bbox <- sf::st_bbox(wshed)
lakes <- fwapgr::fwa_feature("fwa_lakes_poly", bounds = bbox)

Get modelled fish habitat data

Finally, let’s get modelled fish habitat data within our bounds. Note, this is in a different schema (not the default ‘whse_basemapping’ schema). We’ll reclassify the ‘fish_habitat’ column as ‘fish habitat’ or ‘not fish habitat’.

habitat <- fwapgr::fwa_feature("modelled_habitat_potential", schema = 'fish_passage', columns = "fish_habitat", bounds = bbox)

habitat$habitat <- grepl('non fish habitat', habitat$fish_habitat, ignore.case = TRUE) %>%
  ifelse('not fish habitat', 'fish habitat') %>%
  factor(levels = c('not fish habitat', 'fish habitat'))

Make a map!

Things will look better if we clip the habitat and lake layers to the watershed. We’ll use sf::st_intersection.

habitat <- sf::st_intersection(habitat, wshed)
#> although coordinates are longitude/latitude, st_intersection assumes that they are planar
#> Warning: attribute variables are assumed to be spatially constant throughout all
#> geometries
lakes <- sf::st_intersection(lakes, wshed)
#> although coordinates are longitude/latitude, st_intersection assumes that they are planar
#> Warning: attribute variables are assumed to be spatially constant throughout all
#> geometries
ggplot2::ggplot(data = yakoun) +
  ggplot2::geom_sf(data = wshed, lwd = 0.15) +
  ggplot2::geom_sf(data = habitat, aes(color = habitat), lwd = 0.2) +
  ggplot2::geom_sf(lwd = 0.3) +
  ggplot2::geom_sf(data = lakes, fill = "steelblue", lwd = 0.1) +
  ggplot2::theme(legend.title = element_blank(),
                 legend.position = "bottom")
